G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: The amount in controversy is less than $50,000, and therefore this Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: The amount in controversy is less than $50,000, and therefore this Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of a residential tenant’s premises and is liable for damages if the tenant’s enjoyment is disturbed by circumstances for which the landlord is responsible or about which the landlord unreasonably fails to act.

*See e.g., Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass..raw_text: *See e.g., Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (failure to repair conditions affecting safety and livability held to violate quiet enjoyment)
*See e.g., Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass..proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair known security defects can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*See e.g., Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment to cover a landlord’s reckless or at least non‑intentional interference with tenants’ safety and habitability, expressly tying “quiet enjoyment” to serious conditions violating sanitary and safety duties. While the facts involve recurrent flooding and unsanitary conditions rather than security locks, the court’s reasoning is general: a landlord’s knowing failure to remedy conditions that foreseeably endanger tenants or substantially impair livability constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. That logic directly extends to known security defects.
*See e.g., Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 378 Ma.raw_text: *Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 378 Mass. 758 (1979) (landlord liable for interference with tenant’s quiet enjoyment from unremedied conditions)
*Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 378 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair known security defects can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 378 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly upholds the trial judge’s conclusion that the landlord’s failure to repair the leaking roof constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and reviews damages under that statute. While the specific defect here is a leaking roof rather than a classic security device (e.g., locks), the principle is that a landlord’s failure to remedy known conditions that substantially interfere with habitability can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it supports the broader proposition that unremedied, known defects—including security defects—can amount to such a breach.
*Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 378 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises…. Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment."

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.raw_text: *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (quiet enjoyment breached by substantial interference even without intent)
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair known security defects can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns noise and disturbances from a lounge operated by another tenant and the landlord’s responsibility for that disturbance; it does not address security defects or failures to repair security-related conditions. While it stands for the broader rule that substantial interferences within the landlord’s control can breach quiet enjoyment even without intent, it does not specifically involve or analyze security defects, so it cannot be cited as direct authority for that narrower proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The case is not a general premises-liability decision, but it does reaffirm that under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord has a duty—grounded in at least negligent conduct—to avoid conditions that interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, including failure to repair known defects. The court notes that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects in leased premises has frequently been deemed a violation of § 14, which fits within the broader proposition of a duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions, though here in the specific context of quiet enjoyment and lead paint.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….

*Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1.proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Hemingway v. Brennan is a criminal case involving a murder conviction and issues of confessions, expert testimony on insanity, evidentiary rulings, and a motion for new trial. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, premises liability, or any duty of a landlord to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions. Citing this case for a landlord’s maintenance duty is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s subject matter or holdings.
*Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1.relevant_excerpt: There was evidence that Muriel Beal, a young woman twenty-six years of age, was shot by the defendant on Main Street, one of the principal business streets of Brockton, at about 12:15 p.m. on Monday, November 21, 1949. … The defendant does not deny the facts of the shooting. His defence is insanity. … A motion for a new trial … was denied by the trial judge.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case directly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and grounds liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of the landlord’s financial inability. This squarely affirms a landlord’s duty to maintain residential premises free from dangerous or seriously disruptive conditions (here, lack of heat) and to provide injunctive and damages relief when that duty is breached.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided… and (c) an assessment of damages…”}

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns rent control overcharges, security deposit violations, warranty of habitability damages, and allocation of responsibility for heat and hot water under the State Sanitary Code. It does not articulate or analyze a general landlord duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions as a matter of tort or general landlord-tenant law. In fact, the tenant’s separate counterclaim for negligent maintenance of the premises was dismissed and not appealed, so the case does not serve as authority for the proposition cited.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
"The tenant has not appealed from the dismissal of her counterclaim which alleged that the premises were negligently maintained."

"Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case holds that a residential lease includes an implied warranty under which the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition, and that failure to provide adequate heat and hot water is a material breach entitling the tenant to rent abatement. This is a clear affirmation of a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from serious, dangerous, or disruptive conditions affecting habitability, fitting the proposition for which it is cited.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” … The judge found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability.

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Hemingway v. Brennan*, 326 Mass. 556 (1950); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987); *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005); and *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition groups Jablonski with cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions. In Jablonski, the Appeals Court applies existing Massachusetts law on the warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment, but ultimately finds no breach and no serious interference, emphasizing the landlord acted promptly and adequately. The opinion does not expand, newly affirm, or particularly emphasize a general duty beyond restating Hemingway and related precedents; it is mainly an application finding no liability on these facts.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: During the rental of any premises for residential purposes, whether pursuant to a written or oral lease and whether for a specified term or as a tenant at will, there exists an implied warranty of habitability requiring "that the premises are fit for human occupation." Boston Hous. Authy. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973). . . . The landlord promises to provide and maintain residential premises in a habitable condition. The tenant promises to pay the agreed upon rent for the habitable premises.

*Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir.raw_text: *Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2002) (interpreting Massachusetts law)
*Kelley v. LaForce*, 288 F.3d 1 (1st Cir.proposition: Other cases affirming a landlord’s duty to maintain premises free from dangerous or disruptive conditions include *Al-Ziab v.
